bug.short_desc: [Cheat Sheet Authoring] Preview unsaved cheatsheet

long_desc.thetext:
The 'Preview' button is so prominent in the cheatsheet editor that I keep wanting to press it.
However, currently, you have to save the file every time you want to preview it.
It would be good if we used to dirty file buffer contents to populate the cheatsheet view, without forcing the user to save every single time.
I am not sure what the input for a cheatsheet view is expected to be. I hope it can take a plain input stream or a string.

An existing TODO on my list. I'm currently using the following UA API class to open the cheat sheet: org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets.OpenCheatSheetAction.
As far as I know, it only takes a URL as an input. We can put in a request to the UA team to update the API to allow String or stream input.
However, my original plan was to implement the preview function like this: * Save dirty model to temporary file on click of preview button * Use URL to temp file as input to open cheat sheet action (if not dirty just use the actual editor input file)
I believe this solution would be like how the extension point schema HTML file is generated and opened. Thoughts?

I would prefer to stay away from temp files.
For the browser, we have no other choice. With the cheatsheet view, more flexibility should be possible.

Patch: patch_157603_2006-09-26_14-23.txt Target: 3.3 M3
Patch released to HEAD.
Work Done:
* Implemented feature to serialized current model (saved or unsaved) into a String containing raw XML representation -> Pass to new open cheat sheet action constructor created by Chris Goldthorpe

bug.short_desc: [Jobs] The following rule does not apply: Don't swallow InterruptedException. Call Thread.currentThread().interrupt()

long_desc.thetext: Setting the bug description back to what it looked like before I added myself to the cc list.

This looks like a bug in the example to me. I believe the rule you quoted does apply.
BTW, if you frequently call operations that may throw InterruptedException, you don't need to check for isInterrupted(), assuming that you handle the exceptions appropriately by re-throwing or calling interrupt().
Example code fixed.

> However, it's worth noting that the Java interrupt mechanism is not generally > used by Eclipse for handling cancelation (partly because it's so poorly > specified that this is what it is intended for, and anyone could throw it for > some other reason). Instead, Eclipse almost universally uses IProgressMonitor > in long running or blocking operations where cancelation support is needed.
Unfortunately, Thread.interrupt() is the *only* way to terminate a blocking call (see bug 157604). A long running call that is in a blocking call cannot be canceled by IProgressMonitor, because Thread.interrupt() is not called.
oops, I mean see bug 162577

bug.short_desc: ClassCastException when preview report with text item and onPageBreak event handler

long_desc.thetext:
Description: ClassCastException when preview report with text item and event handler.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Preview attached report which map the text item to attached java class
Expected result: No errors.
Actual result: ClassCastException.
Error logs: java.lang.ClassCastException at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.script.internal.LabelScriptExecutor.getEventHandler(LabelScriptExecutor.java:108) at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.script.internal.LabelScriptExecutor.handleOnPageBreak(LabelScriptExecutor.java:96) at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.executor.OnPageBreakLayoutPageHandle.onPage(OnPageBreakLayoutPageHandle.java:257) at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.layout.html.HTMLPageLM.pageBreakEvent(HTMLPageLM.java:170) at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.layout.html.HTMLPageLM.end(HTMLPageLM.java:211) at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.layout.html.HTMLPageLM.layout(HTMLPageLM.java:90) at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.layout.html.HTMLReportLayoutEngine.layout(HTMLReportLayoutEngine.java:80) at org.eclipse.birt.report.engine.api.impl.RunAndRenderTask.run(RunAndRenderTask.java:194) at org.eclipse.birt.report.tests.engine.EngineCase.runAndRender(EngineCase.java:465)
Possible cause: TextItemExecutor.executePlainText(IContentEmitter) treats textcontent as instance of LabelContent. It will cause OnPageBreakLayoutPageHandle.onPage(long, Object) calls LabelScriptExecutor.handleOnPageBreak() instead of TextItemScriptExecutor.handleOnPageBreak.

bug.short_desc: Use EMF proxies to enable proxying for single associations

long_desc.thetext: Teneo eagerly loads all single occurence associations. This because cglib proxying resulted in class loading problems. Another option instead of using cglib proxying is to make use of the emf proxy concept. To accomplish this the id of the an object should be

To accomplish this the id of the object should be encoded in the uri together with the package uri.
Also the current resource implementations should be adapted to handle proxy resolving with database reads.
For Hibernate cglib proxies are now supported (0.8.0 release), this makes it unnecessary to implement emf proxying.

bug.short_desc: Set synchronized flag to false when user changes a descriptor

long_desc.thetext: When a user modifies a descriptor in a process she most likely does not want her changes to be overwritten during synchronization, but she might forget to deselect the isSynchronized flag. Hence the tool should be default set the flag to false when a descriptor is modified. When a descriptor is created the flag should be set to true and stays on true until the descriptor is modified for the first time. Then the tool should set it to false for the user automatically.

bug.short_desc: Can create two plug-in with the same name in linux.

long_desc.thetext:
OS: All linux (find on RHL4U4) Build: 1.0-RC1-N20060915-2030
Step: 1. Create a plug-in, with default name "new_plug-in". 2. Create another new plug-in, type a space after the default name, thus to be "new_plug-in ". 3. Click finish. -->Problem: The space in the second plug-in name was automatically trimmed, thus a second "new_plug-in" created.
4. Create a new ContentPackage in the second plug-in. -->Problem: The first one become unsolved.
Remark: 1. No this problem under windows, in which the finished button was still disabled when type a following space. 2. This is not a regression problem.
Created an attachment (id=50353) Unsolved plugin name

Created an attachment (id=50503) patch for fix
Windows does not allow trailing spaces in filename, but Linux does. The check for duplicate plug-in name is based on the existence of a file with that name. On Windows, the trailing space is automatically removed by the File object, but it is not on Linux.
Solution: the wizard page should call trim() on the plug-in name before validating.
Patch applied
Verified in build 1.0-RC2-N20060919-1705-linux and fixed.

bug.short_desc: problem to XML Import: Merge CP

long_desc.thetext:
version:epf-composer-1.0-RC1-N20060915-2030-win32
Steps: 1 XML Export a library, which has plug-in, configuration, content package 2 create a CP and a task, and DnD the task to the CP, save all 4 import the exported library and select "Merge" 5 Open the CP and find the task descriptor, but the reference to the task is lost. there is no-reference-error(model.xmi) in Problem View.
remark: Now if select "Merge" to XML import a library, then the CP existed only in base library will be reserved, but content method elements(like tasks, roles) existed only in base library will be removed. So if CP has references to those elements, then references will be lost after merging.
expected result: remove the references during merging, or reserve all content elements(roles, tasks,etc), or just remove the CP as same as "override". I feel the second one is best.
Please review this.
The behavor is as designed for "merge" option since CP is a package. But I do agree with Luke's remark -> the designed behavor is not ideal.
The behavor is as designed and the same as regular configuration import too. The work-around or better practice is to make sure that all elements a CP refers to are also in the imported lib.
Keep it open. May fix it later

This is how the system works. Since your added tasks are in an existing package, after the merge import, those tasks will be deleted. As a result, the Activity that references them will lost the references.
If you want to preserve the newly added elements, you should add them into a new package instead of an existing one.
newly added CPs and DPs will not lost since they are ProcessComponents.
We should add this into our release notes.
This is as designed, and there is no plan to change the designed behavor.
verifid the behavior in build v20070418-1717

Created an attachment (id=51455) Screenshot
1. I downloaded http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/download.php?file=/technology/ecf/org.eclipse.ecf.sdk-0.9.1.S20060906.zip 2. Unpack ... to DIR 3. UpdateManager ... New local Site ... select DIR 4. Check this DIR and Callisto-Update-Site too 5. Finish 6. Select "ECF" ... (Error occurred) 7. "Select required" has no effect
Jordi Mulet Albiach please increase the priority and serverity of this bug. Currently i can't install new plugins/features because this error :/ I cant belive that only *we* have this problem?! :)

i found a solution (fix?!)
go into eclipse\features\org.eclipse.gmf.sdk.experimental_1.0.0.v20060627-1200
and change in feature.xml the line
<import feature="org.eclipse.gmf.sdk" version="1.0.0.qualifier"/>
into
<import plugin="org.eclipse.gmf.sdk" version="1.0.0.v20060627-1200"/>
Now you can use the update-manager without errors.

How did this get introduced...I'm an eclipse update newbie.
alan

bug.short_desc: DBCS32: invalid charset Shift-JIS is thrown with NL pack

long_desc.thetext:
Description: org.eclipse.ui throw Shift-JIS is invalid character Set when opening a properties of a project or a file. This occurs if NL pack is installed.
Build date: 3.2 GM or 3.2.1 dated 20060915. NL pack GM, or latest. IBM JVM 5.0 SR2 OS: WindowsXP Japanese sp2 Steps to recreate problem: 1-unzip NL pack on to Eclipse 2-create a project (File > New > Project > General > Project) 3-RMB at the project, and select properties
Expected output: Shift-JIS is really invalid MINE name, but such an error message hsould not be displayed to open a property. It's not occure without NL pack.
Created an attachment (id=50354) screenshot

Fuse-san, could attach the text of the Error log entries?
Kit, could we have a file(s) in the Japanese NL fragments with an invalid encoding? Please take a look and let me know if you need any help.
It could have something to do with the fix for Bug 22982 added to 3.2. Karice, please investigate.

I used the 3.2 catalogs and SDK and am not getting the same result (on both my English XP machine, which has the Japanese locale installed, and a Japanese XP machine). I displayed the result of java.nio.charset.Charset.isSupported("Shift-JIS"); in a Java scrapbook page and got true for both machines. So Shift-JIS appears to not be supported on your machine, Fuse-san. This seems odd, doesn't it? Kit, were you able to replicate the problem?
The message is written to the .log file everytime the encodings are accessed, which includes everytime the Info page of a property dialog is accessed and when the Workspace preference page is accessed. The .log file is where we would want such messages to be written tobut perhaps the message should say it is an unsupported character set, rather than an invalid character set, so as not to raise alarm to users that use the PDE Error Log view.
"Shift-JIS" and "JIS" are listed as encodings in the org.eclipse.ui.nl1 fragment. Fuse-san, you don't seem to be getting an error message about the "JIS" encoding (from looking at the attachment). Is it perhaps a machine configuration problem? Do you think these encodings should not be included in the nl1 fragment? What VM are you using? I used Sun JDK 1.5 VM.

Karice,
Thank you for your investigation. My JVM is IBM 5.0 SR2. JVM encoding names were subject to changed in the past releases. I think we should not use undocumented name. We should select from the supported Encodings list; for 1.4.2, http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/guide/intl/encoding.doc.html for 5.0, http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/guide/intl/encoding.doc.html for 6.0 beta, http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/technotes/guides/intl/encoding.doc.html

Created an attachment (id=50444) modified fragment for org.eclipse.ui.nl1
I've confirmed that worked fine with both IBM JVM 5.0 SR2 and Sun 1.5.0_08.

The Windows-31J encoding probably doesn't make sense to have in the linux/solaris nl packs.
Also, I wonder if there are other encodings we should be including for other languages in this and/or the other nl fragments.

Created an attachment (id=50537) NL1 extra encoding
I've added most likely dominant encodings for Chinese, Korean, Japanese and Windows Latin-1. Adding all of supported encodings will get big combo box list, that would be usability issue.
For NL2, NL2a, NLBidi NLpack, I think that would be an enhancement in the future release.
Kit, I am going to assign this bug to you since the changes only go into the nl packs.
I've confirmed that this issue has fixed in the NL pack 3.2.1.
Closing.

bug.short_desc: [Wizards] 'Change Sharing' should be possible on multiple projects

long_desc.thetext:
I20060918-0010
'Project context menu > Properties > CVS > Change Sharing...' should be possible on multiple projects. Almost always when I need to change the CVS connection, I need to do it on multiple projects at once.
One way to solve this would be to support opening the CVS Properties page on a multiselection. Another way would be to add 'Change Sharing...' as an action to the Team context menu.
The action should not care too much about the selected projects. A batch change should also be possible when the selected projects use differing (or even incompatible) connections.

This is sort of possible today by changing the properties of the repository lcoation in the Repo view. However, this changes the sharing for all projects mapped to the repo. Providing a Change Sharing for multiple projects would require a new UI gesture since the current operation is available on the properties page which is only available for single selection. We do not plan on addressing this for 3.3.

Expected result: Show the actual image effect.
Actual result: One is shrinked in size and the other is cutted. If you previewed the images in firefox, horizontal and vertical scroll bar will appear around the svg image, you have scrolled to see the whole image.
Created an attachment (id=50355) butterfly.svg
Created an attachment (id=50356) cloth.svg
If the user defined the size of the image, the image should be scaled, otherwise, the image should use its content size just as JPG.

This bug contian tow problem: 1.Two svg images behave different in the same browser. 2.The cloth.svg behaves different in IE and Firefox.
For the problem 1: The result is correct, because the two svg images contian different properties. You can use some tools open the two svg image files and see the properties.
For the problem 2: This is a bug of Firefox's SVG Project. I have submitted a enhancement bug to the mozilla, and the bug number is 353450 The bug link: https: //bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=353450 The link of Firefox's SVG Project: http://www.mozilla.org/projects/svg/

Firefox decided not to enhance this svg display problem today. They give a solution: edit the svg file and change the size information from width="28.691cm" height="19.2746cm" to width="100%" height="100%".
Obviously we shouldn't use the solution Firefox gived on BIRT. So I set this bug as wontfix.

bug.short_desc: org.apache.ant doesn't import junit.framework

long_desc.thetext:
The org.apache.ant code doesn't import the junit.framework package. Therefore, the ant-junit.jar isn't able to locate the junit/framework/Listener class, and as a result of which, running tests with the org.eclipse.test.coretestapplication and a formatter of formatter=formatter=org.apache.tools.ant.taskdefs.optional.junit.XMLJUnitResultFormatter fails, because although org.eclipse.test correctly depends on org.apache.ant and org.junit, the class for the parent of XMLJUnitResultFormatter (i.e. junit/framework/TestListener) can't be resolved, because org.apache.ant doesn't have a hook to org.junit.
The code was shuffled around in the 3.2 timeframe (and it's a bug in 3.2 as well; I'm raising it as a bug against 3.3 because it's not fixed in 3.3 either by the looks of it).
This allows me to run tests with coretestapplication and the XMLJUnitFormatter:
Import-Package: junit.framework;resolution:=optional
I recommend this be added to org.apache.ant's manifest file (http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/org.apache.ant/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF?rev=HEAD&content-type=text/vnd.viewcvs-markup)
I believe this should also be a candidate for 3.2.1, as it is a missing dependency that prevents using the XML formatter, which is the most commonly used formatter for automated builds. In addition, makign it a resolutional one doesn't prevent org.apache.ant being used if org.junit is not present (in fact; it behaves just as the current one does).

Thank you for the bug report.
This has been a long standing issue (bug 36198) and the details are outlined in the duplicate.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 36198 ***
Closing as duplicate.

bug.short_desc: Distinguish between different deow statements in the Visualiser

long_desc.thetext:
If I write two aspects, each with advice then they are given a different colour in the visualiser. However, if I do the same with deow statements, they are all grouped together as deow's and given the same colour. This makes it hard to work out which deow statement is affecting which line of code. It would be good if you were able to do this.
The reason this would be useful is if you have a large code base and you're using deow for code exploration. For a first pass you might write a fairly generic pointcut, with one deow statement. However, as you investigate further it might be useful to split this pointcut into several and understand which deow is affecting which code. You are currently unable to see this in the visualiser.
There are two extensions to this original enhancement:
1. Provide the capability to assign different colours to different deow statements within the same aspect (this could then extend to provide the same feature for advice) - it could be a pain having to create new aspects for each statement
2. Enable filtering of deow statements in the visualiser. If you have an aspect whose relationships you're not interested in then it would be nice to have the ability to turn this one off in the visualiser but still see the one's you are interested in. At the moment its a blanket "on" or "off" for deow statements.

bug.short_desc: Drag and Drop on Gnome / Linux doesn't work with network servers

long_desc.thetext:
If you drag and drop resources from a remote server using the gnome filemanager (nautilus) into eclipse resources it doesn't work at all. It should work in the same way as a local drag and drop from nautilus.
If you drag and drop from eclipse resources to a remote server using the gnome filemanager then the files are transferred but end up in the root of the destination fileserver rather than the location you dragged them to. Once again this should just work like it does with local files.
The exact setup i have is that i access remote servers using nautilus via the SSH option on Fedora Core 4.

I assume this is referring to drag/drop to and from the Navigator view. The underlying mechanism used here is the SWT org.eclipse.swt.dnd.FileTransfer class. There are a number of possible problems:
- Nautilus isn't setting the drag data correctly for remote files - Nautilus is setting the drag data in a format that Eclipse is not expecting - SWT FileTransfer is incorrectly deserializing the file paths - Eclipse workbench is interpreting these file paths incorrectly.
Can you try running the simple attached snippet (add to workspace and right click > Run As > SWT Application). It will open a window. Drag some remote files from Nautilus into this window and report here what you are seeing. It just dumps the data being returned by the native DND code.
Created an attachment (id=50418) SWT test snippet

(In reply to comment #1) > Can you try running the simple attached snippet (add to workspace and right > click > Run As > SWT Application). It will open a window. Drag some remote > files from Nautilus into this window and report here what you are seeing. It > just dumps the data being returned by the native DND code.
I get an NPE because data=null

So the event.data is turning out to be null when using the SWT FileTransfer. I don't know if this is a problem in Nautilus, or whether there is a problem on the SWT side in marshalling/unmarshalling the data. Copy/Paste also fails for remote files. Moving to SWT for further analysis.

Thanks, I tried the test script. Whilst processing the event SWT makes a call to FileTransfer.nativeToJava which in turn makes some native calls to retrieve a pointer to a filename - which I presume it uses later for a local file copy operation. I was slightly suprised it was getting the filename rather than the data but perhaps this is the way drag'n'drop usually works.
Anyway the native calls to get the filename start with a call to OS._g_filename_from_uri which returns an error "158776640" - hopefully that is a pointer to an error and not an error code! Anyway, it fails to get the next pointer and nativeToJava ends up returning null.
If the drag'n'drop support is based on filenames then it may be non-trivial to fix (particularly dropping from remote to local). To investigate further would require digging around in the native code and looking up how the GTK drag'n'drop protocol is suppose to work in this case :)
Here is the stack trace where the error occurs:
OS._g_filename_from_uri(int, int[], int[]) line: not available [native method] [local variables unavailable] OS.g_filename_from_uri(int, int[], int[]) line: 1509 FileTransfer.nativeToJava(TransferData) line: 158 DropTarget.drag_data_received(int, int, int, int, int, int, int) line: 351 DropTarget.Drag_Data_Received(int, int, int, int, int, int, int) line: 246 OS._gtk_main_do_event(int) line: not available [native method] OS.gtk_main_do_event(int) line: 5245 Display.eventProc(int, int) line: 1133 OS._g_main_context_iteration(int, boolean) line: not available [native method] OS.g_main_context_iteration(int, boolean) line: 1427 Display.readAndDispatch() line: 2838 DNDTestSnippet.main(String[]) line: 45
Need to investigate why the GTK call is failing. I remember problems dragging to and from Nautilus but this was a long time ago.
g_filename_from_uri doesn't like URI of the file that comes from the ssh server. It seems to want a file:// url.

Perhaps g_filename_from_uri is returning the ssh:// remote file url?
I guess at the moment SWT is just getting the URL and using java to access the file directly on disc. For remote drag and drop to work from nautilus it might be neccessary to wrap the gnome VFS or (ick) re-implement support for all the different protocols (ssh:// nfs:// ftp:// etc,) in java.
This is all just total guessing though, I didn't dig around in the native code, perhaps it can already interface with the gnome VFS.
In any case if the VFS stuff is not supported perhaps there is a way to visually indicate that the drag won't work when you try it...
(In reply to comment #7) > g_filename_from_uri doesn't like URI of the file that comes from the ssh > server. It seems to want a file:// url. >
Bogdan: have fun ;)

With recent additions to Eclipse like EFS and RSE we might be able to handle URIs which identify (remote) files in a pluggable fashion.
Bug #196176 is somehow related, asking for an extension of the SWT FileTransfer for supporting remote files (i.e. where the file is not immediately available as a local path, but rather an URI or a Stream; such that the actual file transfer can only be performed by means of a callback once the drop has occurred).

bug.short_desc: Sibling decorations traversed in wrong order when decorations disposed

long_desc.thetext:
When decorations is disposed, a list of sibling decorations is traversed in dispose method, towards the beginning of the list and then again from the end to find the one that will get focus.
It seems however that the list should be traversed in the opposite direction (method traverseDecorations should be called with true instead of false) beacuse the current behaviour gives focus to the bottom decorations instead of the next-to-top-most one one the top-most one is disposed.
Snippet showing the problem will follow shortly.

Created an attachment (id=50372) Snippet showing the problem
Close the top decorations and you will see that the bottom one gets focus which is not what one would expect.
In my snippet, I just noticed that if you first click on the main window's title bar and then close the decorations, then it works as expected. I don't know the difference though.
Fixed > 20060918 (Jimi Hendrix died today in 1970)

bug.short_desc: BIDI:StyledText Selection of text, and BIDI formating not correct

long_desc.thetext:
When working in RTL mode (G.O = Right_To_left) in styledtext, the selection of text is not ok (first line especially).
Also look at the hebrew line, there is a question mark there after a few words. When the widget is in RTL and the text (hebrew) is one line the "?" appears ok. When the line breaks, the BIDI structure goes haywire, and the "?" goes to the start of the line. This is not the correct behaviour.
Also look at the direction of the selection (When RTL need to be selection flowing left, across multiple lines).
Upper styledText - starts as LTR - hit CTRL+Shift to recreate the widget with opposite orientation. Middle styledText - starts as RTL - hit CTRL+Shift to recreate the widget with opposite orientation.
Bottom styledText - Hit CTRL+Shift to switch orientation (not recreate the widget).
The reason for the 3 widgets is to show that its not the fault of the setOrientation method.
Related to bug 156213: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=156213

bug.short_desc: IStructuredSelection should implement Iterable

long_desc.thetext: IStrucuturedSelection should implement java.lang.Iterable. That would allow a programmer to use the "foreach" version of the for statement on it.
Sorry, but at this time JFace cannot use @since 1.5 API since it is designed to run on older versions of the Java class libraries as well.

(In reply to comment #1) > Sorry, but at this time JFace cannot use @since 1.5 API since it is designed to > run on older versions of the Java class libraries as well. >
But that's not what's needed we only have to add the Iterable-Interface which is part of Java-1.3 and so this should be fine and we already provide the iterator()-method!
Created an attachment (id=50382) The patch

The fact that I don't see the type, plus the following bug suggests to me that Iterable was added in 1.5: http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=6213423

The issue with filters had more to do with drawing the viewer; so we turned redraw off while we were adding the filters so that the tree wouldn't repaint for each new filter. This probably wouldn't be solved as well using that mechanism.
I suspect you'd still pay the performance hit because the work done by the filter exceeds the work to repaint the viewer; whereas before, turning off redraw was useful since it was the biggest cost (not any particular expensive filter computation).
Using a Job might make sense here to add filters; but the tree would continue to redraw itself while filters were added. It might be a bit worrisome only due to the fact that now you've got potentially more than one thread intiailizing the viewer.
The given scenario is easy to fix. The call to getAdapter in the NamePatternFilter is unnecessary. I fixed this > 20060921
See also JDT Core bug 133141.
verified in I20061031-0656

bug.short_desc: "RESOLVE LATER" has become a synonym for "NEVER"

long_desc.thetext:
A comment to http://jroller.com/page/eu?entry=clicking_less_is_good made me realize there is something fishy how bugs are handled.
Often, a bug will not be serious enough or deemed impossible when it is submitted. These are set to resolve LATER.
What happens now is that these bugs disappear from the radar. The developers are never bugged about them, the reporters forget about them.
I ran a query and found over 5000 bugs set to LATER, the first one is Bug 30 reported in 2001 ()!
I think there are two ways to solve this:
- When a new release of eclipse comes out (before the plan items are fixed), Bugzilla should send out mails to the reporters of all bugs which are set to LATER
- On a release, all LATER bugs are reset to OPEN
Also, when a duplicate of a bug is reported, LATER bugs should be reconsidered. There are probably many LATER bugs which have tons of duplicates. If each duplicate would count as a vote, these bugs might rank highest in the "most annoying" list.

Sorry that I have to say it that way but the comment on the blog is nonsense.
Each team/project makes their own decision on how to work with Bugzilla. There are no official guidelines and even if there were, they would be guidelines and not rules. BTW, AFAIK the only rule is openness. ;)
I know of at least two teams which don't loose bug reports in the RESOLVED LATER state. In fact, over the past few years I submitted and subscribed to bug reports which got into the RESOLVED LATER state but were REOPENED and FIXED later.
It is true that RESOLVED LATER in almost all cases means "I can't work on this right now". But by all means it never means "You are not allowed to contribute a patch for this."
Anyway, I suggest closing this as INVALID because it's not a real bug report for the Eclipse Bugzilla. On the other hand, closing as WORKSFORME would work too because AFAIK the Eclipse Bugzilla provides the necessary feature (also known as "whining", the WTP folks is using it for verifying bugs). It just has to be enable by the component leads *if* they want to use it in their team.

> I know of at least two teams which don't loose bug reports in the > RESOLVED LATER state.
Well, if two out of N (where N is large) do it, that's an argument against the current handling, isn't it? :-)
> In fact, over the past few years I submitted and subscribed to bug > reports which got into the RESOLVED LATER state but were REOPENED > and FIXED later.
And I submitted a lot of bugs which never got REOPENED which is why I opened this bug :-)
I'm not sure if I get the correct bug count when I run a query with just "LATER" as condition. Some math: My bug is number 150'000, I get 5000 LATER bugs which is 3%.
That doesn't seem much. But from those 5000, many are resolved by now. So it would be really good if someone "had" to peer over them at least once a year.
To take the pressure off the team, I suggest that you send mails to the reporters so they can take another look. If many cases, this will close the bug or people will add a comment to the effect that something similar was fixed/implemented elsewhere in Eclipse. While this doesn't solve the issue, it will help to fix/close more bugs more quickly.

I think this is an interesting discussion, but I think Gunnar makes a point: RESOLVED LATER in almost all cases means "I can't work on this right now". And I think in some cases it means "we have no plans to do this is the near future" - and this could be for a million reasons, one of them being limited resources.
IMHO, I don't think it should be up to the teams to be reopening RESOLVED/LATER bugs. I think it's up to the community to either a) track their bugs and ask committers to reconsidered them in a later version or b) to step up to the plate and do everything they can to get the bug solved, either by contributing code patches or by gathering community feedback or c) accept that, without additional help, the bug may be RESOLVED/MAYBESOMEDAYBUTNOTTODAY.
> To take the pressure off the team, I suggest that you send mails to the > reporters so they can take another look.
Not everything is solved by bugging folks with e-mails. You can easily run an RSS feed of the bugs you have reported and are RESOLVED/FIXED.
> Some math: My bug is number 150'000, I get 5000 LATER > bugs which is 3%.
I think that's awesome. Only 3% of bugs are RESOLVED/LATER? Wow. But I got curious and ran some queries for you:
mysql> select count(*) from bugs; +----------+ | count(*) | +----------+ | 156641 | +----------+ 1 row in set (0.00 sec)
mysql> select resolution, count(*) from bugs group by resolution; +------------+----------+ | resolution | count(*) | +------------+----------+ | | 22540 | (NEW bugs) | DUPLICATE | 21850 | 14% | FIXED | 76111 | 48.6% <-- woot! | INVALID | 9460 | 6% | LATER | 5034 | 3.2% | REMIND | 1455 | | WONTFIX | 8574 | 5.5% | WORKSFORME | 11617 | 7.4% +------------+----------+
Total fixed/dupe/worksforme/invalid: 76%
Total new/invalid/later/remind/wontfix: 24%
Hat's off to the committers for being so responsive.
Also,
| 13 | helpwanted | Indicates that the committers are requesting help in working on this bug. |
mysql> select count(*) from keywords where keywordid = 13; +----------+ | count(*) | +----------+ | 788 | +----------+
There are currently 788 bugs with the "helpwanted" keyword. Here's the resolution breakdown for those helpwanted bugs:
mysql> select a.resolution, count(*) from bugs a, keywords b where b.bug_id = a.bug_id and b.keywordid = 13 group by a.resolution; +------------+----------+ | resolution | count(*) | +------------+----------+ | | 304 | | DUPLICATE | 48 | | FIXED | 113 | 14.3% !! Woot! | INVALID | 10 | | LATER | 207 | | REMIND | 11 | | WONTFIX | 72 | | WORKSFORME | 23 | +------------+----------+
Hat's off to the community for providing help when help is requested!
> Anyway, I suggest closing this as INVALID
How about closing it as RESOLVED/LATER? Oh, it's funny, laugh ;)

(In reply to comment #3) > IMHO, I don't think it should be up to the teams to be reopening RESOLVED/LATER > bugs.
Again, this is project/team dependent. I remember that I reopened such a bug once and after that was kindly ask not to do this until I also attach a patch to it. ;)

>> To take the pressure off the team, I suggest that you send mails to the >> reporters so they can take another look. > > Not everything is solved by bugging folks with e-mails.
But the LATER bugs get easily lost because they take such a long time to fix.
> You can easily run > an RSS feed of the bugs you have reported and are RESOLVED/FIXED.
How do I do that? I only know how I can save queries.

(In reply to comment #5) > But the LATER bugs get easily lost because they take such a long time to fix.
How would you know that a bug is lost? You can't say which Bugzilla queries the project owners run.
> > You can easily run > > an RSS feed of the bugs you have reported and are RESOLVED/FIXED. > > How do I do that? I only know how I can save queries.
Scroll down the search results page. There are links to get the result in many different formats. One of them is the "Feed" link, which basically just appends "&ctype=atom" to the search link.

Many of the platform project teams used to reopen all LATER bugs after each release. This created an annual cycle of LATER > REOPENED > LATER > REOPENED that benefitted nobody and generated a large amount of unnecesary bugzilla spam each year. Most teams eventually gave up with reopening LATER bugs each year... it's just as easy to query LATER bugs as it is to query OPEN bugs, so it doesn't add much benefit. I agree that bugs marked LATER often get lost, and there are likely some in there that are actually now FIXED, INVALID, or DUPLICATE. However, that's probably also true for a large number of the 22,540 open bugs - there just aren't enough committer resources to comb through every single bug report to make sure they are still valid and not duplicated.
My only suggestion is to feel free to add a comment in the bug to update its status... such as "This bug still occurs in Eclipse 3.2". That is very useful information that can help the committers with their triage work, and lets them know that there are people in the community who still care about it. Unfortunately, updating bugs with truly useful information like this cannot be done automatically. Sending blanket emails for all LATER bugs or automatically reopening them would not be useful in the slightest. You would only succeed in annoying and wasting the time of everyone CCed on the bug.

There's a big problem with duplicate bugs, though. If a bug was raised against (say) 2.1, and someone reports it against 3.2 (or 3.3), it gets closed as a duplicate of the bug in 2.1. Yet, because the 2.1 bug is RESOLVE LATER, and it's against the 2.1 release, no-one ever looks at it again.
The stats of the duplicate bugs (14%) suggest that a lot of duplciates get raised. But, as I mentioned in the blog entry about it, if you raise a bug and it gets closed in Eclipse Relase N, you have in effect blocked it from ever being fixed in N+1, N+2, N+3 ...
The main problem is that a duplicate (bug raised in Eclipse N+1) doesn't update the bug to bring it back in-scope for the current release. Let's face it, someone's *telling you* it still exists in Eclipse N+1, and it's being closed "We knew about this in Eclipse 3.1, but we didn't have time to fix it then, so we'll never have time to fix this in Eclipse 3.2". And, as a reporter of (many) duplicates, I don't have permissions to change the bug's version number from (say) 2.1 to 3.3 to bring it back in scope.
So, is it possible to use MySQL to post stats on the number of RESOLVE LATER that have been duplicated with a different Eclipse version number? I.e. to pick out a full list of the bugs that were reported both in Eclipse N and Eclipse N+1, but where Eclipse N+1 is reported as a dupe of Eclipse N?
I offer as evidence bug 6038 (a four-digit bug number; wow, that's low!). Raised in 2001, it's as valid now as it was then. It was originally released against Eclipse 1.0. It was updated to 2.0, then deferred (the good old RESOLVE NEVER).
Bug 37153: Raised against Eclipse 2.1. Closed duplicate. Bug 38870: Raised against Eclipse 3.0. Closed duplicate. Bug 77139: Raised against Eclipse 3.0. Closed duplicate. Bug 129006: Raised against Eclipse 3.2. Closed duplicate. Bug 158282: Raised against Eclipse 3.3 (by me :-). About to be closed duplicate.
People have been complaining about this for *years*. And yet, it's not shown up on anyone's radar since Eclipse 2.0, because it was RESOLVE LATER then, and it's still RESOLVE LATER now. Is it on the bug fix plan for 3.3? No. Why not? Because it doesn't show up on any reports that have '3.3' in the version number.
And yet, each of those bugs were reported by people, letting the appropriate teams know that the bug was still valid. However, they couldn't change anything about the original bug, nor could they up the version number to show that the bug is still valid.
John's suggestion (comment #7) about adding a comment "This is still valid in Eclipse 3.2" is what people have been doing by filing duplicates. What should happen is that the duplicate should be upped to represent the current version number, and reopened when someone reports a duplicate. Otherwise, it will just stay in the stale RESOLVE NEVER state.
Note: bug 6036 has been updated since it was originally filed against 1.0 to reflect the fact that it is still valid against the 3.3 builds, and reopened. It was reopened by the original reporter, because he's still interested in making Eclipse a better place. Unfortunately, those reporters have often moved on (to a new e-mail, to a different product) and don't care about upping the version or reopening the bug when someone else points out that it's a duplicate.
When a bug is reported as a duplicate, the buzilla system should reopen the bug automatically and up the version to the version that was reported against (if it's bigger). Then, these sorts of problems go away. The teams get notified by people that bugs still exist against newer versions, and only those bugs that are still valid get re-reported.

I think Alex raises some very interesting points, the best one them being that if a bug is marked as a duplicate of an old bug, it is definitely an indication that it's still applicable today. Fair enough. Alex: 1 Committers: 0.
However, in the case of some bugs like bug 6038, let's remember that is isn't a bug - something broken with the software - it's an *enhancement request*, and Darin consistently repeated that resources were lacking and that prioritization issues didn't allow them to consider it. No committer resources? Fair enough. Alex: 1 Committers: 1
So, my $1,000,000,000 question is this: how are committers supposed to handle bugs and enhancement requests that don't make it on their list of priorities, or for which they do not have the resources to fix them? What should Darin do for bug 6038?

(In reply to comment #9) > So, my $1,000,000,000 question is this: how are committers supposed to handle > bugs and enhancement requests that don't make it on their list of priorities, > or for which they do not have the resources to fix them? What should Darin do > for bug 6038?
Flagging it as "helpwanted" would be a good option to indicate willingness of accepting patches from the community.

> If a bug was raised against > (say) 2.1, and someone reports it against 3.2 (or 3.3), it gets closed as a > duplicate of the bug in 2.1. Yet, because the 2.1 bug is RESOLVE LATER, and > it's against the 2.1 release, no-one ever looks at it again.
My interpretation of the "version" field is that it only indicates the version of Eclipse in which the bug was first entered. If a bug is resolved later, an old version number doesn't indicate that the bug is no longer valid - it is still a valid bug until the resolution changes to something like WONTFIX or INVALID.
> if you raise a bug and it gets closed in Eclipse Relase N, you have in effect > blocked it from ever being fixed in N+1, N+2, N+3 ...
That's not the case. For example, here is a query of platform bugs that were fixed during 3.2, but were reported against 2.x releases (60 bugs). Many of these bugs passed through the LATER state at some point, before being reopened and fixed:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/buglist.cgi?query_format=advanced&short_desc_type=allwordssubstr&short_desc=&classification=Eclipse&product=Platform&version=2.0&version=2.0.1&version=2.0.2&version=2.1&version=2.1.1&version=2.1.2&target_milestone=3.2&target_milestone=3.2+M1&target_milestone=3.2+M2&target_milestone=3.2+M3&target_milestone=3.2+M4&target_milestone=3.2+M5&target_milestone=3.2+M6&target_milestone=3.2+RC1&target_milestone=3.2+RC2&target_milestone=3.2+RC3&target_milestone=3.2+RC4&target_milestone=3.2+RC5&target_milestone=3.2+RC6&target_milestone=3.2+RC7&long_desc_type=allwordssubstr&long_desc=&bug_file_loc_type=allwordssubstr&bug_file_loc=&status_whiteboard_type=allwordssubstr&status_whiteboard=&keywords_type=allwords&keywords=&bug_status=RESOLVED&bug_status=VERIFIED&bug_status=CLOSED&resolution=FIXED&emailtype1=substring&email1=&emailtype2=substring&email2=&bugidtype=include&bug_id=&votes=&chfieldfrom=&chfieldto=Now&chfieldvalue=&cmdtype=doit&order=Reuse+same+sort+as+last+time&field0-0-0=noop&type0-0-0=noop&value0-0-0=

(In reply to comment #6) > How would you know that a bug is lost? You can't say which Bugzilla queries > the project owners run.
My definition of a lost bug is: LATER and last comment is older than two years (maybe even one year; Eclipse moves so fast :-)
(In reply to comment #7) > You would only succeed in > annoying and wasting the time of everyone CCed on the bug.
So actually this is not a bug in Bugzilla but more like "we need a Bugzilla etiquette" where such ideas are collected: Reporter: Run a query on later at least once a year or create a RSS feed, etc.
As it is, I reopened several of my LATER bugs and got some feedback ("don't do that"). A concise etiquette would help here.
(In reply to comment #7) > When a bug is reported as a duplicate, the buzilla system should reopen > the bug automatically and up the version to the version that was reported > against (if it's bigger).
+1
(In reply to comment #11) > here is a query of platform bugs that were > fixed during 3.2, but were reported against 2.x releases (60 bugs)
But doesn't this depend on how teams handle this? Are teams told that they should ignore the version number on queries?
I'd think that including the version is something natural and leads to unexpected behavior in this case. So either Bugzilla should update the original bug when duplicates are reported or "do not use version queries" should go into the Bugzilla etiquette.

John, thanks for that Bugzilla query. It's an eye-opener.
If I can summarize what I understand so far:
- RESOLVED/LATER is *not* RESOLVED/NEVER, as John's query proves
- Committers don't have unlimited resources to fix each and every bug and to implement each and every enhancement request, so some bugs will go unfixed
- We can gently "nudge" committers by posting a comment inside an old bug (without reopening it, or updating the version)
- An Enhancement Request doesn't necessarily get more important as time goes by. John, what are the factors that enable Enhancement Requests to make it to a committer's list of to-do's?
- Bugzilla etiquette will be difficult to define, as each project has its own way of working, although we can draft a general etiquette. There's already a Bug Reporting FAQ here, but this page could be moved to the Wiki so that everyone can update it: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugzilla.html

> John, what are the factors that enable Enhancement Requests to make it to a > committer's list of to-do's?
For most committers, there is an effectively unlimited supply of available bug reports and enhancement requests. How they choose what to work on is effectively a cost/benefit analysis. Cost in this case is the amount of work to address it, the work of ongoing maintenance for a new feature, the ripple cost a new feature may have on downstream projects, performance cost, etc. Things that increase the "benefit" side include benefits for end-users of Eclipse applications, benefits for downstream projects, etc. Also, input from the community in the form of votes, and input from the PMC and from committers on other projects increase the "benefit" side of the equation. A long-dormant bug may be reopened either because the cost has gone down (perhaps some underlying infrastructure is now available that makes the problem easier to solve), or the benefit has gone up (more requests from users, committers on other projects, the PMC, etc). If the cost/benefit ratio of a bug does not change, it may remain unaddressed forever.
Here's another fun stat while we're throwing queries around. There are 60 committers on the Eclipse project who have committed code in the past three months (platform, jdt, pde, equinox), according to dash (http://dash.eclipse.org/dash/commits/). Meanwhile, there are 13148 open bugs, and another 4640 in the LATER state. That's roughly 300 bugs/enhancements per active committer. So, it's certainly true that bugs get missed, but committers are doing their best to identity and resolve the bugs that have the most value for their time.

Would it be possible to allow arbitrary bugzilla users to update the "version" field? That would give users another mechanism to indicate that their bug is still applicable to a newer release (although I'm not sure many committers ever run queries based on version).

Thanks for the explanation, John. Here are some action items I can list from the comments I read in this bug:
- The Bug Reporting FAQ at https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugzilla.html needs to be moved to the Wiki -> I volunteer to do this
- The wikified Bug FAQ needs to be updated with the information John typed in comment 14 (in response to the FAQ "How can I get my enhancements in the committer's queue") -> I voluneer to do this to spare John's time (allowing him to work on bugs ;)
- A new Wiki page, called Bugzilla_Etiquette, needs to be created and linked to from the above page -> Any takers? Aaron, are you interested in writing this up?
Am I missing any other action items?
D.

Sorry if I missed it, but one suggestion I didn't see in the above comments was that 'later' and 'remind' not be in a 'resolved' state ... perhaps it should be a new state called "onhold"?
After all the normal bugzilla help says "RESOLVED A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by QA. From here bugs are either re-opened and become REOPENED, are marked VERIFIED, or are closed for good and marked CLOSED" https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/page.cgi?id=fields.html#status
And, since "remind" and "later" are not even listed in that standard help, I wonder if they are an "eclipse invention"?
BTW, just FYI, some of us projects (try) to document our bugzilla process, at least as it comes up, or questions are asked on mailing lists, etc, see http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/WTP_Bugs%2C_Workflow_and_Conventions

I'm sure my views don't represent those of all committers - I suggest after drafting some guidelines you mention it in your next Webmaster update to see if other committers have a different point of view. I suspect each project uses bugzilla, and the various status and resolution states, in their own way.

I'm adding Alex as a cc, as I think this bug may interest him.
The Bug Reporting FAQ at https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugzilla.html has been moved to the Wiki: http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Bug_Reporting_FAQ
My next step is to expand the FAQ. New FAQs include: "How can I get my enhancements in the committer's queue?" and "Why do some bugs stay open for years?"
I'll draft up some answers then invite the committer community to edit them as required.
Is anyone interested in creating a new Wiki page, called Bugzilla_Etiquette? Anyone?

(In reply to comment #17) > And, since "remind" and "later" are not even listed in that standard help, I > wonder if they are an "eclipse invention"?
They're part of the default Bugzilla install. The docs must be stale.

(In reply to comment #18) > Is anyone interested in creating a new Wiki page, called Bugzilla_Etiquette?
Interested: Yes. But as time permits, I can only promise an initial version with the thoughts collected from here and what I've been experiencing with my bugs.

(In reply to comment #21) > Interested: Yes. But as time permits, I can only promise an initial version > with the thoughts collected from here and what I've been experiencing with my > bugs.
This would be fantastic - thanks.
I've updated the Bug Reporting FAQ to include the Why do some bugs stay RESOLVED/LATER for years?

I'll boldly close this as Fixed:
- comment 14 offers great insight from a committer's point-of-view - the bugzilla FAQ have been refactored and moved to the wiki - the bugzilla FAQ have new content - a wiki page called Bugzilla_Etiquette has been proposed, but not yet created, but Aaron has volunteered to create one as time permits
Although RESOLVED/LATER bugs won't get magically fixed because of what has been accomplished here, we now have a better understanding of what is required to make issues progress in a way we'd want them to.
I would also mention that it is possible that some of the bugs closed as RESOLVED LATER are actually fixed. However it would take a huge amount of time to review all of them.

In that case, may I suggest that the RESOLVE LATER is just disposed of? It doesn't seem to serve any practical purpose. If no-one knows whether a bug in RESOLVE LATER is OPEN or RESOLVED, it's not looked at by committers, and they're supposed to stay open -- why not just leave it in the OPEN state? That way, everyone would be happy. If they are looked at by committers as OPEN, then why not treat it as the same? There's a bunch of bugs that were OPEN'd against (say) 3.0 that are still available in the DB.
It would be better if the RESOLVE LATER bugs were changed to OPEN with a target of LATER.
May I suggest that that would be a good way of handling it?

> It would be better if the RESOLVE LATER bugs were changed to OPEN with a target > of LATER.
The resolution field is only associated with the RESOLVED state. Also, there is no OPEN state, there is only NEW and ASSIGNED. Neither of these seem appropriate for bugs flagged as "LATER" (they're not new bugs, and they're not assigned to anyone).

IMNSHO they're both better than RESOLVE, because they're not resolved. At least NEW and ASSIGNED are open states.
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/page.cgi?id=fields.html#status (note this is also available at Eclipse:) https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/page.cgi?id=fields.html#status
Note that the Bugzilla states have UNCONFIRMED, which is the default level that bugs are filed with; they're only moved to NEW once they've been confirmed. It would seem that if Eclipse followed this policy, then you could easily use the NEW state to represent open bugs, and then address these kind of issue with NEW and a target of LATER.

I've just understood part of comment 26: "The resolution field is only associated with the RESOLVED state"
Yes, I know ... but then, a bug that is still open shouldn't be marked as RESOLVED in any way :-)
I was suggesting addressing the Target Milestone field (which all bugs have, including this one) and having a milestone of 'Later', as opposed to reusing any kind of resolution field.
Those on this bug might like to comment/vote on bug 178923 in which he proposes removing LATER and REMIND with the migration effort to bugzilla 3.0
I'm fine with REMIND and LATER, but not with them being associated with RESOLVED. So if the choice is RESOLVED/LATER or not, I go with not. If we could have an OPEN/LATER, that would be even better.

Bjorns idea is a good one - we use REMIND to keep the bug alive pending more details and LATER to indicate "not on the plan".
Reducing our ways of bug management would be a bad idea. -1 to removing these constants

bug.short_desc: Regions are allowed to own connection points (entry / exit pseudostate)

long_desc.thetext: The spec clearly allows this since a region can own * subvertex of type Vertex. However, I'm not sure this makes any sense semantically. The connection points define an interface for creating transitions to a state machine or composite state.

Yes, entry and exit points can be owned by regions - this is intentional. There used to be constraints that restricted ownership of entry/exit points to topmost regions, but these have been removed to allow them on any region - see http://www.omg.org/issues/uml2-rtf.html#Issue8611.

Intentional perhaps, but it still doesn't make any sense to me. Is the idea such that there can be logical entry / exit points for transitions between regions inside a composite state or state machine?

bug.short_desc: old classes not updated when new classes with same name added in a new package

long_desc.thetext: Our product based on jem 1.2.1 has a scenario where there is a binary class A in a folder f1. During processing A.java is created in folder src. At that the package of test for A.java is also created. After this jem api reflecting types return the A.class in folder f1. They correctly return A.java in folder "src" if the workspace is restarted.

There is a problem that we are basically ignoring that a package from one root has been added. Because of this if there is another root that had the same package we wouldn't mark the contents stale and so we wouldn't see the changes.
The fix is a simple fix but this is a big problem.
Rich, it looks like this fix is planned for 1.2.1. Is that correct?
Has been released to VE 1.2.1 M20060918 build.

bug.short_desc: Error if try to replace a diagram img file, checked in under source control

long_desc.thetext:
The problem is in the GMF class CopyToImageUtil (org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.render.util) in the methods saveToFile() and createFile(). If the selected image file already exists, then createFile() will do nothing and then the logic in saveToFile() attempts to write the image data onto the existing file. Since the file in ClearCase is read-only, the write fails.
The method createFile() should do some extra processing if the file already exists; verify that the file can be edited (e.g., ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().validateEdit()) and if not, abort the image saving.

Created an attachment (id=53471) Proposed fix.
Validate edit is added to the CopyToImageUtil (for SVG, GIF, BMP, JPG) and ImageExporter (for JPEG, PNG).
The patch (53471) has been code reviewed by Cherie.
Committed the patch to R1_0_maintenance and head.

bug.short_desc: [Undo] Undo not working as expected

long_desc.thetext:
We ran into this issue while working on some DTP components.
When entering text into a text box field in the New JDBC Connection wizard, editing operations don't work correctly. For instance, if we type something into the URL field, and then paste something else, then hit "Undo", it should remove what was pasted but leave what was typed. Instead it removes both.
This is very consistent with many text boxes tested in Eclipse. Any thoughts?

The behavior depends on how the paste was done.
- if you type something, and then simply paste without changing the cursor position or selection, then you would observe the behavior you describe (the undo would undo the typing and the paste) - if you type something, change the cursor position or selection, and then paste, then the undo treats the paste as a separate operation.
This is the standard platform text undo behavior on Windows, and unlikely to change since we do not attempt to interfere with platform behavior.
If you are seeing different behavior, then please describe a scenario in the base Eclipse SDK that demonstrates the behavior, as that would mean someone is overriding the platform behavior.
Thanks for the additional information. That helps!
Closing bug.

bug.short_desc: significant memory leak running trace agents

long_desc.thetext:
significant heap growth after running an trace session. memory profiler reveals that TRCInputOutputContainer is ultimately held in memory after the session is over. (see attached profiler stack trace showing retained objects)
Joe Toomey comments: Can you check to see if AgentImpl.processExited() is being called when the agent's process exits? The last statement in processExited() (AgentImpl:745) calls a private method called cleanup() that, among other things, clears the listener collection in AgentImpl, which should break the chain you list below. If it's not being called, I'd try to understand why not.
Created an attachment (id=50401) gif of yourkit based analysis stack showing source of memory leak
Reassign to the right component.

Samson,
It looks like the _listener in org.eclipse.hyades.internal.execution.local.control.ConnectionImpl is never cleanup.

(In reply to comment #3) > Samson, > > It looks like the _listener in > org.eclipse.hyades.internal.execution.local.control.ConnectionImpl is never > cleanup. >
I am referring to method org.eclipse.hyades.internal.execution.local.control.ConnectionImpl.disconnect()
As per conversation with Eugene, he meant to reassign the owner when he reassigned the component. Changing the owner to the default owner in bugzilla.
Assigning to Samson.

What agent are you running? Logging, Test or Profiling? I can't seem to reproduce the leak using TPTP logging/test/profiling agent. Can you try to recreate the problem using TPTP only and attach your project in the bugzilla? Thanks.

We are running a custom agent that uses RemoteComponentSkeleton. I doubt you can recreate this problem using just the TPTP agents alone. To my knowledge, TPTP's agent's don't use the entire trace model (as our custom agent is doing so). Primarily, we are storing information in the trace option component (as per Marius' recommendation), which is then stored in the trciovxmi model component. I have never seen TPTP's agents store data in here, even though the models supports this. As a result, I'm unsure how we can create a canned TPTP scenario alone if TPTP itself isn't exploiting its own models the way its marketed to be used.
Nonetheless, if you want to provide patches we can help test them out. Looking at the stack it looks like the trciovxmi component of the model has some handle to the lower level AC component. If this handle is freed, we should be safe. Samson, do you think you can create some fix/patch that we can try?
If this is not possible, please propose a solution to determine how solve this problem. Frankly speaking, I don't believe its acceptable that only a TPTP canned test scenario should be the only point of validating this error, because TPTP itself is a "platform" (as stated by the last "P" in the name). Hence, its intended to be extended or consumed in various different manners. It would be inconceivable for the platform itself to handle all the various ways it could be extended - if it did then a canned TPTP test scenario would be in order - but this is not reality.
Target to 4.3 w/o iteration - awaiting triage.
Set target to 4.2.1.

This leak appears to be caused by a combination of factors. Unlike the TPTP profiler, the consuming product re-uses the workbench side AgentImpl when collecting data from an application server that never exits (and thus never calls processExited.) Eugene tells me that when the agent is detached using the TPTP profiler, it is not reused, and is available for gc.
The memory leak is caused by an orphaned reference to the MultiplexDataServer object which is created and added to the AgentImpl._listener collection in the startMonitoring() method, but is not removed in the stopMonitoring method. Even in the detach() method, which nulls out the _server_mux variable (which holds the references to the MultiplexDataServer), the reference in the _listener collection is not removed. This results in pinning the associated data processor in memory (since the MultiplexDataServer holds a reference to it), which subsequently pins the whole trace model.
Attaching a patch, still need to review this with Samson to make sure I haven't misunderstood anything about this multiplexing. Will send jar file patch to submitter to verify.
Created an attachment (id=53114) patch file -- apply to org.eclipse.hyades.execution plugin project
Committed to HEAD for 4.3 GA candidate. Still need to commit to 4.2.1.1.
Per discussion on mailing list, I am retargeting this defect to 4.3 (where it is already checked in). I will open a new defect to check this into 4.2.1.1.
Closing...

attachment.desc: gif of yourkit based analysis stack showing source of memory leak
patch file -- apply to org.eclipse.hyades.execution plugin project

bug.short_desc: JavaModelListener, JavaReflectionSynchronizer is very slow in determining if a project is in its classpath

long_desc.thetext:
We found JavaReflectionSynchronizer/JavaModelsListener really slow in building a medium/large workspace in WTP and WTP based product, it gets called by the builder, validator etc taking 30-40% of total time spent during build, validation.
The listener adds itself to java model and spends a lot of time in determining whether any event that occurs belongs to a project the listener is interested in.
There are a few things here which is why the we are seeing the problem and a fix anywhere could help alleviate the problem.
1. Apparently JDT does not provide any event information when a project is added/removed from a classpath container. see bug 154071 So the listener has to listen to every change in JDT model and figure out the classpaths of all its projects and see if the event happens in one of its projects (really ineffecient)
2. A lot of java events are generated in building the workspace, many of which can and cannot (as of now) be wrapped in java model operation so as to send less notification.
3. The listener calls flexibleclasspathcontainer to resolve its classpath entries in its event handling code, and this container currently delegating it to its extn pt implementors for the classpath entries and somewhere in there they are not caching/optimizing the classpath entries lookup. see bug 157337
4. The listener itself can be a little smarter, if it adds a singleton listener to the java model (instead of one per WTP project, I saw like in one case with 80 WTP projects 80 java model listeners out of a total of 82 java model listeners). By doing this (singleton) we achieve a way of making all listeners per project share their search results to each other. Rather than everyone of them going out and resolving classpath containers. Its upto the implementor to determine what information can be cached to get good returns. We found that we were able to remember the returns of the classpath container's entries in a cache and reduce the time taken in resolving entries, EVEN if the cache is cleared at the end of the event handler. I know this did not make it as fast as it should be, (that is if the problem were to not be ther e in the first place). but its still better than now. Please find a implementation, attached.
Created an attachment (id=50405) listener sub class
Created an attachment (id=50406) listener super class

Hi Rich,
I opened this bug to acknowledge that the problem exists and if not possible as of now to address it , help address it in the near future.
Thanks Raj
Seeing the dependent JDT bugs are being concidered for 3.4... targeting this for 3.0

Hi Chuck, now that Bug 154071 has been fixed in eclipse 3.4, should try to fix this bug in JavaModelListener/JavaReflectionSynchronizer we might get significant performance benefits especially as we do not have to listen to all types of events.
See also bug 176454

bug.short_desc: [Sync View] Synchronize view should turn off redraw when toggling filter mode

When changing from incoming to outgoing, etc., the Synchronize tree can be seen animating as it expands and collapses treeitems. This can take a long time if the tree is large. The fix is to avoid windows' animation by turning off redraw, updating the tree, and turning it back on.
Part of the problem is probably caused by the nature of the update. It seems like treeitems are not reused in a way that relates to the similarity in what is being display before and after. So you see the same project disappear, and then reappear, and the expansion state is repaired due to the lack of reuse of the treeitems.

bug.short_desc: Dynamic help search not working on Application Client wizard in Japanese

long_desc.thetext: In the Application Client wizard, in the Japanese locale, the Dynamic Help search does not provide any results. When launched in English, the Dynamic Help search does provide results.
Created an attachment (id=50410) Screen capture of Application Client wizard in Japanese

Created an attachment (id=50411) Screen capture of Application Client wizard in English
The Dynamic help search results is working in English but not Japanese.
Kit, I don't know where this problem is originating (ie is it my fault or a problem with the NL). Any chance you could take a look?

I have a few questions for clarification. 1) Does this problem only happen with dynamic help? What if you open the help system "Help->Help Contents" and search there? Are there hits? 2) Does this only happen with WTP installed? What if you try this just with the Eclipse SDK and its NL packs? 3) Are we certain that the translation used by dynamic help is the same that was actually used in the documentation? 4) Is this only failing on the latest SDK (assuming it fails with only the SDK in #2? This is, is this a regression from Eclipse 3.1 to 3.2? (I think 3.1 is when dynamic help was added.) And depending on the results from #1, there is a similar regression question that could go back much further.

I investigated more and found something interesting (and that could be the bug.)
The first time we click on the "Help" button on the "New Application Client Project" wizard, the context help title "New application client - page 1" is passed to dynamic help as the search expression. (You can see the search expression by pressing the "More results" link at the bottom of the Dynamic Help section.) In Japanese, this will result in 0 hits.
However, if we click on the Back button and Next button again, then "Application Client module" OR "New Application Client Project" is passed to dynamic help as the search expression. In Japanese, this will result in 8 hits, listing topics containing either the "Application Client module" string or the "New Application Client Project" string.
Interesting, I didn't know that the context help title would show up in the GUI. (Usually we leave them blank). Perhaps the title needs to be changed?

bug.short_desc: ServerPublishInfo is not properly updated after removing the application from the server

long_desc.thetext:
Server publish info is not properly updated and this results in the server status changes even after the applications are removed.
To Reproduce: 1) Create a server (v6.1, or over version v5.1, v6.0) 2) Create a Dynamic Web project and add JSP in it 3) Add the project to server (from server view) 4) Remove the project 5) go to Jave editor and edit the JSP then save Now you will see the server status changed from "Syncronized" to "Republish"
The problem is that serverpublishinfo still shows the modules in it even after the application is removed. The modules were not removed in ServerPublishInfo.removeDeletedModulePublishInfo() method due to that the moduleList is empty. Where the moduleList is optained from getModule() which obtains a list of mudules that have already removed. We may have to use different approach to retrieve a list removed manules and then use them to update the server publish info.
Problem happens to both v6 and v5.1 servers.

Step 5 is the most troubling part. The server should still have publish info (so that the module can be removed correctly), but it should not use that info during resource change events when determining what is currently on the server.

Tried to reproduce and could not. The difference between the steps listed was that when I made the change in step 3 or step 4, the server status correctly went from "Syncronized" to "Republish". If I republished (or auto-publish kicked in) between these steps, the status would correctly go back to "Syncronized". I could never get step 5 to change the server status.
ServerPublishInfo should continue to contain the old modules until after a successful publish. Updating the server status is done using a job so it may not update immediately after a change, but the job does have the correct locks should it should not be possible for it to get out of sync.
The bottom line is that I was unable to reproduce this. If you can still reproduce on WTP 1.5.2, please wait between the steps to see if/where the status changes and this was just a case of a delayed update. Please feel free to reopen if you have additional details, or clarifications on how to reproduce.

Tim, in step 3) or 4) I did not make any change to the JSP. I did the change at step 5) after the project was removed from the server view. The complain in this defect is that when the project is no longer in the server view, the server status should not change as the JSP changed.
I did tried on the latest version, problem still exists.
In your case, after you removed the project from the servers view, can you do a publish again? Then the state should change to "Synchronized". Then you go to edit the JSP in the project and save the change. This will result in the state change from "Synchronized" to "Republish". Is this correct behavior? I think it is not because at this point, there should be no link between the conten of the project and the server.
Let me know whether you agree.
Thanks,
I still see the problem. Please refer to my previous note for details.

Discussed offline with Ian. The problem is that the publishModule() method of the adopter server adapter was missing a call to setModulePublishState(module, IServer.PUBLISH_STATE_NONE). This flag tells the server framework that the module published correctly and the publishing state can be reset. Without it, the publishing state eventually gets out of sync.
Ian will add the line into the adopter product, so I will be using this bug to improve the javadoc to reflect this requirement.
Released to 2.0 builds.
Oops - correcting milestone target to 2.0M4.
Closing as fixed since M4. If this was closed in error, please reopen.

bug.short_desc: [Help] Gray out help button when no help

long_desc.thetext: If dynamic help is not available for a certain box that you have the focus on, the help button should be grayed-out instead of confusing the user by not doing anything when you click on the help button.

Not sure if we want to do it this way or not - context-sensitive help isn't the only thing useful when you click the help button. You can also see the table of contents, search, and browse the keyword index.

Perhaps just the help button for Dynamic Help should be grayed-out and not the entire help feature such as table of contents, search, and browse? The user can still have access to those features but just not through the Dynamic Help button.

That's what I was referring to actually.. the help tray that appears inside the dialog. If the user is at page 7 of 8 of a long and complicated wizard, they would need to completely cancel out (and later start over) in order to get to Help -> Help Contents, however with the help button they could keep the wizard up while browsing.

bug.short_desc: OSGi JarVerifier needs clearer separation of verification and trust

long_desc.thetext: The current implementation of the OSGi JarVerifier should have a clearer separation of the independant operations in verifying a Jar, including verification and trust. We would also like to support pluggable trust provider, a la JSSE TrustManager.
Could you help us in creating this separation and providing a patch?
Absolutely. Eric Li (cc'd) has been working through some proposed changes with Tom Watson. Expect a patch in the next couple days.

Created an attachment (id=52165) patch for the OSGI JarVerifier component
Here is the summary in this patch:
1. Support verifying only one signer. If there are multiple signers, the JarVerifier uses the later signer 2. Seperate the parsing of signature block file and determination of trust for a chain of certs 3. Adding a CertificateTrust OSGI Service, and there is a default OSGI CertificateTrust service with minimum serivce ranking 4. Support parsing timestamp

Created an attachment (id=53944) Check root certificate for trust
The last patch did not properly check the root certificate for trust.
Eric please review the change. I modified the CertsTrustVerifier.checkTrust to check the trust of the last certificate in the chain. I assume the last cert in the chain is the root certificate. Is this correct?

Plan to release this for M4.
There is a need for an option to assign trust to bundles based on certificates but to not do runtime time verification of the jar content.
In such a scenario the bundle content would be verified by update when a feature/bundle is installed. From this point on we assume the content is good, but we still want to associate the certificates with the bundle. Currently we have an option osgi.support.signature.verify that enables runtime signer support. This currently enables the following
- Certificate parsing of signed bundles at runtime - Establishment of certificate trust - Load time verificate of each bundle entry to detect tampering
I will investgate adding more options to osgi.support.signature.verify intead of just true and false flag. Maybe the value of the option can be a list of features to enable. Something like the following:
certificate - enables parsing and verification of certficates
trust - enables verification of certificate trust (this option implies certificate)
runtime - enables verifidation of bundle content at runtime (this option implies certificate)
true - same as specifying osgi.support.signature.verify = certificate,trust,runtime

Created an attachment (id=54026) patch
I did some more review and cleanup of the code in this patch.
- added enablement options to the osgi.support.signature.verify option. This option can not take a comma separated list of features to enable
certificate - enables parsing and verification of certficates
trust - enables verification of certificate trust (this option implies certificate)
runtime - enables verifidation of bundle content at runtime (this option implies certificate)
all | true - same as specifying osgi.support.signature.verify = certificate,trust,runtime
I renamed CertificatesTrustService to CertificateTrustAuthority and changed the addTrust(Certificate[] certs) method to addTrusted(Certificate[] certChain)
I reworked the way CertificateTrustAuthority services are discovered. The previous patch would check a security property "CertsChain_Trust_Service" for an implementation class. Then it would search all CertificateTrustAuthority services registered and compare their implementation class with the value of CertsChain_Trust_Service. I changed the security property from to "CertsChain_Trust_Service" to "osgi.certificate.trust.authority". I changed it so that this security property refers to a value of a service property.
For example the default trust authority service is registered with osgi.certificate.trust.authority=org.eclipse.osgi as a service property. It is also registered with the lowest service ranking. To force the default trust authority to be used you can add osgi.certificate.trust.authority=org.eclipse.osgi to your java.security file.
I optimized for the case when osgi.support.signature.verify=trust. This will likely be the most common setting used at runtime. In this case a fully signed eclipse build takes an additional 1000 ms to launch to a java perspective. The additional 1000 ms seems to come from the one call to CertificateFactory.getInstance("X.509"). I cannot think of how to avoid that unless we want to write our own CertificateFactory ;-)
Using osgi.support.signature.verify=runtime takes a considerable amount of memory and CPU time to verify the checksums of each bundle entry at load-time. Using this setting is not recommended except for extremely paranoid people ;-)
I would like to release this patch very soon (like tomorrow). Eric and Matt can you take a look at my changes and let me know if they are acceptable to you. Thanks.
Patch has been released for 3.3 M4.
