bug.short_desc: The HTML syntax validation in jsp files should mind the bodycontent declaration of jsp tags

long_desc.thetext:
In the example below a validation warning will be created: unknown tag (myxml). I think that if a tag defines the bodycontent to be tag dependent the HTML validator should not validate the content of that tag. Would such a change be difficult to implement? Or are there other ways to prevent the HTML syntax validator from creating warnings within jsp tags?
test.tld: ... <tag> <name>xmlcontent</name> <tagclass>com.test.TestClass</tagclass> <bodycontent>tagdependent</bodycontent> <info>Tests validation of content.</info> </tag>
test.jsp: ... <body> <test:xmlcontent> <myxml/> </test:xmlcontent> </body>
Is it not complaining about test:xmlcontent as well?

Right. If the bodycontent is set to tagdependet there is another validation warning on <test:xmltag> as well, saying: Missing end tag "test:xmlcontent".
The warning on <test:xmltag> does not appear if the bodycontent is set to JSP for example.

tag dependent content should be ignored ... shouldn't even be being parsed as HTML at all! This may be an artifact of some "well formedness" checker?
But, we'll investigate, and attempt to replicate.

bug.short_desc: PI Agnet extensions create unnecessary trace when profiling in standalone mode with no output file.

long_desc.thetext:
PI Agnet extensions create unnecessary trace when profiling in standalone mode with no output file.
When you use -XrunpiAgent:server=standalone, without specifying a filename, piAgent automatically creates a trace file with a default name. I think initially piAgent was only assumed to be used for profiling, which is why it sends the trace data to a file when profiling in standalone mode. The notion of piAgent extensions was introduced later. This file is unnecessary in the dynamic Probekit use case and its generated because of the way piAgent was designed and how it treats profiling in standalone mode.
For example,
-XrunpiAgent:server=standalone,mode=none,extensionLibrary=ProbeAgentExtension.dll,ext-pk-BCILibraryName=BCIEngProbe.dll,ext-pk-probescript=APIRecorder.probescript
creates the following trace.trcxml file in the current project:

time="1158595392.015624761"/> <agentCreate agentId="94e3e315-da4a-452b-aa17-777e6133b6d0" version="1.000" processIdRef="" agentName="Java Profiling Agent" agentType="Profiler" agentParameters="server=standalone,mode=none,extensionLibrary=C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\APIRecorder_1158595390640/ProbeAgentExtension.dll,ext-pk-BCILibraryName=C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\APIRecorder_1158595390640/BCIEngProbe.dll,ext-pk-probescript=C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\APIRecorder_1158595390640/APIRecorder.probescript" time="1158595392.077999830"/> <traceStart traceId="b4f51623-167d-4767-a8a1-497cbf3690c8" agentIdRef="94e3e315-da4a-452b-aa17-777e6133b6d0" time="1158595392.490825176"/> <option key="CLASS_LOAD_DETAILS" value="false"/> <option key="METHOD_DETAILS" value="false"/> <option key="COLLATION_VALUES" value="false"/> <option key="CONTEXT_FLOW" value="false"/> <option key="FILTERS" value="true"/> <option key="TRACK_GC_EVENT_TYPES" value="frees"/> <option key="ID_STYLE" value="static"/> <option key="OBJ_REF_MODE" value="filterOwner"/> <option key="METHOD_COUNTS" value="false"/> <option key="OBJ_ALLOC_IS_ARRAY" value="true"/> <option key="OPTIONS" value="true"/> <option key="STACK_INFORMATION" value="contiguous"/> <option key="COMPRESS" value="none"/> <option key="TRACE_MODE" value="none"/> <option key="TICKET" value="true"/> <option key="TIMESTAMPS" value="true"/> <option key="TRACE_IDREFS" value="false"/> <option key="UNREFERENCED_SYMBOLS" value="false"/> <option key="CPU_TIME" value="false"/> <option key="LLDATA_ENABLED" value="false"/> <option key="HEAP_INFO_FILE_PREFIX" value="optHeap"/> <option key="MONITOR_MODE" value="none"/> <option bug.short_desc: Update should support permanent persistence of trust

long_desc.thetext:
Currently the IVerificationListener interface supports returning CHOICE_INSTALL_TRUST_ALWAYS, which would seem to imply that the update manager should not prompt the user *ever* again for this signer. This would require that the update manager place the representation of trust into someplace where the Jar verification subsystem (ie: OSGi JarVerifier) could reference it. This does not currently seem to be the case.
If CHOICE_INSTALL_TRUST_ALWAYS is not appropriate because it implies trust across a feature or an update session, then we should add a CHOICE_INSTALL_TRUST_PERSIST to represent the permanent trust.

Created an attachment (id=52166) patch for the update core plug-in
Support certs persistence, if the IVerificationListener returns CHOICE_INSTALL_TRUST_PERSIST, the persistence of cerst will be delegated to a CertificatesTrustService OSGI service. This also requires the patch from the OSGI JarVerifier https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=157669 .

Please update the patch based on the new class/method names for the changes that were released to the OSGi bundle in bug 157669.
Thanks.
I think there is a lot of changes in the new update.core plug-in, do you need me to produce against the old or new update.core plug-in?

Created an attachment (id=58449) update the patch w/ renamed CertificateTrustAuthority
DJ,
The class name change was trivial in the OSGI bundle and it changed from CertificatesTrustService to CertificateTrustAuthority. I just updated the previous patch w/ the new class name. Please let me know if you have any more questions. Thanks.
-eric
Pls also assess how risky it would be to backport the 3.3 patch in 3.2 maintenance branch.
Also, is this committed for 3.3M7?
This looks very scary. I have no experience in this area and cannot release it unless somebody from the Equinox team approves it.
Created an attachment (id=64193) api for persist the trust certs and expired jars
Created an attachment (id=64194) make the class 'jar expired' sensitive

Philippe, the patch can't be applied into 3.2.2 since it requires the changes of OSGI plug-in in M4.
The new patch that I just uploaded works w/ the latest code 3.3M6 update code. I have tested it out. Can anybody on the Equinox Team approve it?
Tom will take a look. We had no prior knowledge of this issue/patch and given the late date, it seems unlikely that we'll get something for M7.

Created an attachment (id=65227) org.eclipse.update.core patch
I am not comfortable with this patch.
It adds new API which will need PMC approval at this point in the release. Asside from that the changes to IVerificationResult adds a new method getCertificates(). The javadoc says "Clients may implement this interface." So any clients will no longer work. I'm not sure if update really supports just anyone implementing this interface but I'm not familiar enough with the code to make that determination, I only have the javadoc to go by. According to the javadoc this would be a binary incompatible change. A new interface would need to be defined which extends IVerificationResults that adds the new method. This patch does *not* address these issues.
I also found a problem in how UpdateCore finds the CertificateTrustAuthority service. This algorithm must be identical to how the framework finds the trust authority. I've updated the patch to make this identical to the framework.
For people having problems with this issue, is there a recommended workaround or suggestion for avoiding multiple prompts?

I admit I scanned the bug very quickly, but there is a button to accept signatures (or lack thereof) for all subsequent features after the one that opened the dialog. So yes, I definitely claim that we probably can avoid them :-).

bug.short_desc: [Dialogs] Global preference to disable Modal Dialogs

long_desc.thetext:
We are running into all sorts of automated testing problems, because various components pop up modal dialogs. When this happens the testcase just hangs, since there is no user there that can respond to it.
To make our product more testable, there should be a global preference (or environment variable) that all components check, and when set, they don't pop up modal dialogs.
This would be a special setting that we would use when running automated tests, and wouldn't normally be turned on when a user was using Eclipse.
Alternatively, we could have our own special version of jface Dialog that APT shut s down automatically. OR, we run a special thread that closes any open dialog box it finds withing 500ms.

My last comment may need some explanation :-)
I was referring to an internal tool we use in IBM. A general Eclipse solution would be good, as Gary suggests.

bug.short_desc: Generate link creation/initialization command in single separate classes instead of duplication of the code in different SemanticEditPolicy'ies

long_desc.thetext:
Consider "by class" LinkMapping L that allows to link nodes of type S to the nodes of type T.
Actually for such link mapping we are generating the complete inner class CreateIncoming<L>Command in the <T>SemanticEditPolicy class. Also we are generating CreateOutgoing<L>Command inner class in the <S>SemanticEditPolicy class.
The problem is that in case if S and T are abstract classes with concrete Subclasses S1, S2, ... and T1, T2 ..., we are generating exact copies of CreateOutgoing<L>Command as inner classes inside all of concrete <S1>SemanticEditPolicy, <S2>SemanticEditPolicy etc.
All of this code is essentially the same -- it just creates and initializes the instance of L's class using the way specific only for L, not for S or T.
Thus, in case if link initialization code should be tweaked with "@generated NOT" code, user needs to change all of them.
Expected: instead it would be really helpful to generate separate command class (in fact, pair of them for incoming/outgoing versions) as top-level class somewhere, and just instantiate it from different <..>SemanticEditPolicies.
Separate classes with creation commands should be generated and used from NodeItemSemanticEditPolicied as well. Helpful the extra- editparts are generated for top-level and different inner elements.

In addition see following newsgroup discussions:
http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.modeling.gmf/msg00825.html (news://news.eclipse.org/edpf7b$rad$1@utils.eclipse.org) http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.modeling.gmf/msg01108.html (news://news.eclipse.org/eeofnp$t3r$1@utils.eclipse.org)
Separate link creation commands generated for TypeLinks.
In addition NodeCreation commands are generated as separte classes form now. This fix can help in the situations then same GenNode nested into the different type of containers.

bug.short_desc: [Help] Extensibility Search Scope

long_desc.thetext:
Online help offers the ability for users to define search scope.
Eclipse-based products' extensibility users sometimes have a hard time finding information relevant to extensibility in search results.
It would help if PDE provided an out of the box "Extensibility" search scope that other SDKs could "join".
I'm not sure why PDE is central to the out-of-the-box experience. did you mean to post to User Assistance or did I miss something?

Wassim, my mistake... sorry
I am not sure if the Help system even supports adding such search scope through extensions. Ideally, a plugin would define a search scope and other plug-ins would bind some of their TOC to this search scope. Assuming this functionality is not available yet, I would effectively say this should go to "User Assistance".
The component that would create that "extensibility scope" should probably be the component that owns the "Platform Plug-in Developer Guide".
The other components (JDT, PDE, etc...) would bind their "Developer Guide" to this "search scope"

It feels like this could potentially make things like the doc for Europa a lot more consistent -- or at least it would *enable* it to be. ;-)
It also seems that this would be useful for product builders.

bug.short_desc: Template driven new plug-in project wizard

long_desc.thetext:
PDE's New Plug-in Project Wizard allows templates to be provided to help users create plug-ins with specific initial behaviour/capabilities.
Our product uses these templates to generate transformation plug-ins. Unfortunately, most new users cannot find this functionality since they don't even know what a "plug-in" is.
To help user find the wizard, we introduced a "New Wizard" under our own "Transformation" category. This wizard simply launches PDE's New Plug-in Project Wizard. Unfortunately this is still counter intuitive since we still show the templates page and not pre-select the "Transformation" one. Ideally, such "template specific" wizard should probably start by the template page and optionally let the use "dig into" the next pages to override project creation defaults.
Selecting the right template from the PDE Wizard sounds like a no-brainer for us Eclipse developers... but customer often do not know anything about Eclipse.
The enhancement request is to offer a reusable wizard that is template driven, as opposed to plug-in driven.

Wassim, do you know what he's on about? <g>
Is this the only solution to the problem? Couldn't we just provide some extra API on the PDE Wizard for selecting the template that he wants?

That would definitely help. However, that still leaves the user confused about having to specify plug-in project parameters when he/she asked for a new transformation. Ideally, the first wizard pages would be the template ones. These would provide valide defaults for the new plug-in project parameters (e.g. plug-in name = transformation name). The user can hit 'finish' as soon as the template pages are done, or can go 'next' to customize the new plug-in projects' parameters.

I need to understand the situation a bit more without diving into implementation details just yet.
Frederic, your main concern here seems to be that your users don't know what a plug-in is and should not be overwhelmed by that concept. That's a fine usability point, but not an easy one to solve because you cannot shield these concepts for too long if you want to get something done with this template.
So let's say we have a wizard that shows templates as the first page. The moment they press Finish and the code is generated, the manifest editor will open and they will very quickly be exposed plug-ins, extensions, launch configurations, etc.
So a New wizard with the new order of pages would have only acted to delay the introduction to the plug-in concept by 2 seconds and we're back to where we were.

I agree bringing up the manifest file is not helping much. I guess this needs to be customized as well. I can easily imagine a transformation manifest file editor opening up instead.
I will continue with the transformation example, I assume this can be generalized. People implementing transformation only need to know about the transformation framework they have to code against. They don't need to know about dependencies, deployment, extension-points, extension, etc... Even launching the transformation is different from running a standard plug-in.
Advanced users will take advantage of the 'plug-in' nature of the transformation, but beginners shouldn't need to know about it.

Frederic, it does not sound to me like you need PDE at all for this. Our constituents are plug-in developers so it makes no sense for us to invest in hiding concepts of plug-ins/extensions points/manifest editors. We are in the business of promoting all these concepts.
What you really need, I believe, is bug 36960, which is to be addressed at the platform level, not PDE.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 36960 ***

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] Save vs. Flush

long_desc.thetext:
Compare viewers have a save lifecycle that is really a flush to the underlying diff node/compare input. In Team, we detect the flush and perform a save. Lately, we added support for file buffers which also saves on a flush. We should try to make this as explicit as possible either through code or documentation.
One thing we should do is add a saveDocument(IDocumentProvider, IDocument, ...) to the ISharedDocumentAdapter. This would allow the compare input/diff node decide whether a flush was also supposed to save.
Also, the flush method has a progress monitor. We should pass that through to the above save. We can't pass it through to the old API so we should document how we do it in Team.
I have updated the code so that ISharedDocument provider has connect/disconnect and save methods and passed the progress monitor for the flush through to the saveDocument.
Verified by code inspection in I20061031-0656

bug.short_desc: [Help] Extensibility online documentation and examples should be based on target environment

long_desc.thetext: Today, the extensibility online documentation (Developer's Guide) and examples (welcome page) are discovered off the development environment. Shouldn't they be discovered off the target environment instead?
Moving to UA as they own Welcome

It would be possible, but certainly non-trivial to implement. Help would need to be aware of what type of content a book has, and would need to load docs from plug-ins outside the run-time environment, like PDE does.
Since this is a lot of time and effort for a relatively small feature, it unlikely to be looked at anytime soon.
Actually this is a really interesting point. If a user is doing development using 3.2 but targteting 3.1, at least some of the doc (e.g., javadoc) they see should be that of 3.1.

bug.short_desc: Unable to load org.apache.tools.ant.taskdefs.optional.ssh.SSHExec in the org.apache.ant plugin in an RCP application

Examining the MANIFEST.MF file, I realized that org.apache.ant plugin does not have require com.jcraft.jsch plugin (not even optionally). Once I edited the MANIFEST.MF of org.apache.ant, the exception went away.
Are there any technical reason for not including com.jcraft.jsch as an optional dependency of org.apache.ant? Is there a way to work around this problem?
You can create a fragment which adds the jcraft dependency to org.apache.ant.

bug.short_desc: [import/export] Import as EAR: validation errors are not shown or logged

long_desc.thetext:
I am experimenting with EJB3 and exported my EAR application as an EAR file. I will attach it. I was not able to re-import it because of an error in the EJB jar. The import dialog talked about an error and promised that more details could be found in the log (I will attach the dialog). But the log file does not show any messages !
This is the core part of this bug report. What comes afterwards is probably an EJB3 enhancement request...
Finally I found my error. I had to finish the import (EJB project was not imported) and there I clicked around the J2EE. After expanding both "KuchenSimpleNoAnnotation\Deployment Descriptor: KuchenSimple\Modules" and "KuchenSimpleNoAnnotation\Deployment Descriptor: KuchenSimple\\UtilityJars" the log showed an error message which pointed me to the problem.
The message was: !ENTRY org.eclipse.ui.navigator 4 0 2006-09-18 22:15:55.656 !MESSAGE Could not acquire children from extension: org.eclipse.jst.navigator.j2ee.ui.EARDDContent !STACK 0 java.lang.IllegalStateException: Parent Translator (EnterpriseBeansTranslator(entity|session|message-driven,8817773)) did not find a Child Translator for "persistence-context-ref". at org.eclipse.wst.common.internal.emf.resource.CacheEventNode.init(CacheEventNode.java:128) at org.eclipse.wst.common.internal.emf.resource.CacheEventNode.init(CacheEventNode.java:96) at org.eclipse.wst.common.internal.emf.resource.CacheEventPool.createCacheEventNode(CacheEventPool.java:79) at org.eclipse.wst.common.internal.emf.resource.EMF2SAXDocumentHandler.addToStack(EMF2SAXDocumentHandler.java:164) at org.eclipse.wst.common.internal.emf.resource.EMF2SAXDocumentHandler.startElement(EMF2SAXDocumentHandler.java:86) at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.AbstractSAXParser.startElement(Unknown Source) at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLNSDocumentScannerImpl.scanStartElement(Unknown Source) at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl$FragmentContentDispatcher.dispatch(Unknown Source) at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.impl.XMLDocumentFragmentScannerImpl.scanDocument(Unknown Source) at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(Unknown Source) at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.XML11Configuration.parse(Unknown Source) at com.sun.org.apache.xerces.internal.parsers.XMLParser.parse(Unknown Source) ...
This pointed me to the problem: the "persistence-context-ref" element in ejb-jar.xml confuses the importer.
So, to sum it up: a) The error message has to be logged (this is the main target of this bug report) b) It would be great if someone could take a look in why "persistence-context-ref" makes import impossible. I can work fine with JBoss/EJB3 and WTP 1.5, this is the first severe problem I encountered.
Created an attachment (id=50429) Screenshot of import dialog with error message

Created an attachment (id=50430) EAR file with sources. Try to import it
I use my modified JBoss serverdefinition from http://www.informatik.fh-wiesbaden.de/~knauf/public/
The Java EE models in 1.5 are not EE5 compliant, and the parser doesn't recognize these elements... This is a R2.0 line item

OK, then the import of this EAR will not work before 2.0. Will have to use annotations then ;-).
But the core problem (which should be fixed in the 1.5 branch) is that the import error is not logged, thus not accessible to the user.
Sounds like the parse error was logged eventually.... These documents will parse fine in 2.0
No, the error was not logged on importing the EAR. It appeared in the log at a later point (after some clicking around in the project).
Changing target to RC0

Wolfgang- if there is a strong enough reason to include it, we could investigate this for 1.5.5 (but it would have to be a customer breakage or somesuch). Otherwise, we will try to improve our logging in 2.0.1.

Nope, it is not of critical importance. I will update to 2.0 as soon as possible.
But anyway, import errors should be reported to the user in an easy to spot way, and the log delay seems strange.
This is working in the 2.0 RC2 driver.

bug.short_desc: [CommonNavigator] Java source directories starting with dot are visible in the Project Explorer view

long_desc.thetext:
The new Project Explorer (aka Common Navigator) view is not filtering java source directories that start with a dot even though the ".* resources" filter is enabled. The JDT's Package Explorer view handles this correctly.
Would like to see this fixed in the next service-pack release of the 3.2 platform as this is a major usability problem for products that use the dot prefix to hide the generated source directories from user's view.

Michael,
Any guesses for when you might be able to fix this?
Thanks,
- Konstantin
Fixed in > 20070422
*** Bug 193164 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

bug.short_desc: Locale specific date parameter value is not accepted.

long_desc.thetext:
BIRT does not accept locale specific date format as a parameter value. 2006/9/18 is not accpted on Japanese locale. But, 9/18/2006 is accepted.
Please check the attached screen shot for detail.
Created an attachment (id=50432) Screen shot of this problem.
DataTypeUtil does this checking.
Locale specific date is not supported in parameters. All date value should be inputted in the specified format.
Created an attachment (id=50961) Screen shot of the test case

Setting the report parameter as accepted format "03/02/2004 12:11:10 AM", BIRT does not return the value. Please check the screen shot of the test case.
Note: if the default value "2004-03-02T12:11:10" is used for dataSet parameter, it returns correct data.
Data has provide APIs in birt.core to handle this issue. GUI should use that API to test the input.
All the choices and default value are stored as string values. They should be unrelated with locale for compare. It was implemented as required.

attachment.desc: Screen shot of the test case

bug.short_desc: task repository creation should ask for email address and not name

long_desc.thetext:
I went to add a task repository, and used the eclipse.org template. It asked for my user name -- but for Bugzilla, it really wants my email address and not my name, e.g. ducky@webfoot.com and not ducky.
The wording should probably change to "E-mail address" to match Bugzilla.

What if we changed it to 'Login ID? Since other issue trackers may not require an email address and that form is somewhat common among the different connectors. In addition, I'm not certain but if Bugzilla is configured to use LDAP then you may login with a user id rather than an email address.

Hmmm. So it sounds like the dilemma is whether keep code compatibility across different repository connectors, or to customize the form for each repository connector. I am not familiar enough with the code to know how much of a pain it would be to customize, but am willing to believe that it's A Bad Idea for now. However, I wouldn't be surprised if someday in that far-off and distant future, it becomes necessary to customize the forms; in that case, somebody should revisit this decision.
As for "Login ID", that sounds to me like it wants "ducky". I'd prefer "Repository ID", with a note that this is frequently username or email address.
(BTW, in my way of thinking, if you are in LDAP mode, your username *is* your email address.)
I need to work on one or two small bugs in order to exercise Mylar, so if y'all don't mind, I'll take this one...
Okay sounds good. Perhaps we could place a hint in the label like (email address)?
How about just "User ID"?

"User ID" also sounds to me like the first part of an email address. I'm willing to be swayed, however, if more people think it should be "User ID".
"Repository ID" makes it clear that it is something specific to the repository, IMHO.
Yes, "User ID" may be best since repository id could be interpreted as the id of the repository. :)
Rob. That is exactly my point. :-)
+1 for "User ID", and not bothering with hints unless there is more indication that they're needed, sine they will need to be repository-specific.
Created an attachment (id=51817) Changes "User Name" to "User ID"
Created an attachment (id=51818) mylar/context/zip
Thanks Ducky, patch applied.
Marking fixed.
